p: In the field, S. lotanalis caterpillars were not found on other plants species, including the other Melastomataceae assessed ( Table 1). However, a similar species, Ategumia matutinalis Guen√©e, was observed attacking C. hirta. Ategumia matutinalis caterpillars are very similar to S. lotanalis, with similar wing color patterns as adults ( Figure 1D). In host specificity tests, S. lotanalis caterpillars were able to develop through to pupation on both C. hirta and the Hawaiian biotype of M. calvescens. In other Melastomataceae, no damage by caterpillars was verified, and they died of starvation ( Table 1).
